body:
Comment 5 by **vincent-google@vinc17.net**: 
> The spec explains the ideal language.

The goal of a spec is to explain what is the real behavior, not an ideal behavior
that doesn't match the reality. You should look at the spec of the other languages.

> The implementation restriction explains the deviations that implementations
> can make from the ideal.

But the spec doesn't show the link between the "implementation restriction" and how
constant expressions are evaluated. In particular because one can do exact arithmetic
based on floating-point arithmetic with limited precision (at least when you are
restricted to the arithmetic operations and the square root), if a spec says that
constant expressions are evaluated exactly, the user is in right to assume that they
are really evaluated exactly.
